abstract: The News Corporation appeared tantalizingly close to succeeding in its bid to acquire Dow Jones & Company.
snippet: The News Corporation appeared tantalizingly close to succeeding in its bid to acquire Dow Jones & Company.
lead_paragraph: The News Corporation appeared tantalizingly close to winning the support of enough members of the Bancroft family to succeed in its bid to acquire Dow Jones & Company last night, but not close enough to conclusively claim victory.

headline.main: Murdoch Awaits Decision on His Dow Offer
headline.print_headline: So Near, Yet So Far: Murdoch Awaits Decision on His Dow Offer

byline.original: By Richard Pérez-Peña and Andrew Ross Sorkin

abstract: BOSTON, July 30 (Dow Jones/AP) — A former senior executive with Prudential Securities is paying $100,000 to settle accusations by the Securities and Exchange Commission that he had failed to supervise registered advisers who the S.E.C. says allowed favored clients to make improper “market timing” mutual fund trades.
snippet: BOSTON, July 30 (Dow Jones/AP) — A former senior executive with Prudential Securities is paying $100,000 to settle accusations by the Securities and Exchange Commission that he had failed to supervise registered advisers who the S.E.C. says allowe...
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, July 30 (Dow Jones/AP) — A former senior executive with Prudential Securities is paying $100,000 to settle accusations by the Securities and Exchange Commission that he had failed to supervise registered advisers who the S.E.C. says allowed favored clients to make improper “market timing” mutual fund trades.

abstract: Rupert Murdoch appears to have enough support from the divided Bancroft family for his News Corporation to buy The Wall Street Journal and the rest of Dow Jones for $5 billion.
snippet: Rupert Murdoch appears to have enough support from the divided Bancroft family for his News Corporation to buy The Wall Street Journal and the rest of Dow Jones for $5 billion.
lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch appeared today to have gained enough support from the deeply divided Bancroft family to buy Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, for $5 billion.

headline.main: Murdoch Seen Winning in Bid for Dow Jones

byline.original: By Richard Pérez-Peña and Andrew Ross Sorkin

abstract: Pearson, the owner of The Financial Times, said that it was talking to a number of potential partners about new ways to display the newspaper’s journalism.
snippet: Pearson, the owner of The Financial Times, said that it was talking to a number of potential partners about new ways to display the newspaper’s journalism.
lead_paragraph: LONDON, July 30 — Pearson, the owner of The Financial Times, said Monday that it was talking to a number of potential partners about new ways to display the newspaper’s journalism as it weighed the effects of Rupert Murdoch’s bid for Dow Jones & Company, owner of The Wall Street Journal.

headline.main: Wary of Dow Jones, The Financial Times Is Looking for a Media Partner
headline.print_headline: Wary of Dow Jones, The Financial Times Is Looking for a Media Partner

abstract: Pearson, the owner of The Financial Times, said Monday that it was talking to a number of potential partners about new ways to display the newspaper’s journalism as it weighed the effects of Rupert Murdoch’s bid for Dow Jones & Company, owner of The Wall Street Journal.
lead_paragraph: Pearson, the owner of The Financial Times, said Monday that it was talking to a number of potential partners about new ways to display the newspaper’s journalism as it weighed the effects of Rupert Murdoch’s bid for Dow Jones & Company, owner of The Wall Street Journal.

headline.main: Wary of Dow Jones, The F.T. Looks for a Partner

abstract: The News Corporation appeared tantalizingly close to winning the support of enough members of the Bancroft family to succeed in its bid to acquire Dow Jones & Company Monday night, but not close enough to conclusively claim victory.
lead_paragraph: The News Corporation appeared tantalizingly close to winning the support of enough members of the Bancroft family to succeed in its bid to acquire Dow Jones & Company Monday night, but not close enough to conclusively claim victory.

headline.main: Murdoch Awaits Decision on His Dow Offer

abstract: As the battle over the future ownership of Dow Jones enters its final stretch, questions about journalistic independence seem to have given way to, well, the green stuff.
lead_paragraph: As the battle over the future ownership of Dow Jones enters its final stretch, questions about journalistic independence seem to have given way to, well, the green stuff.

headline.main: Dow Jones’s Fate: A Question of Fees?

abstract: Rupert Murdoch finally seems to have his grasp around his long-coveted prize, tentatively gaining enough support from the deeply divided Bancroft family to buy Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, for $5 billion.
lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch finally seems to have his grasp around his long-coveted prize, tentatively gaining enough support from the deeply divided Bancroft family to buy Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, for $5 billion.

headline.main: Bancrofts Back Dow Jones Sale to Murdoch

abstract: In the end, writes David Carr of the New York Times, the News Corporation’s capture of Dow Jones was quite simple: Rupert Murdoch wanted it more.
lead_paragraph: In the end, writes David Carr of the New York Times, the News Corporation’s capture of Dow Jones was quite simple: Rupert Murdoch wanted it more.

headline.main: In the End, Rupert Murdoch Wanted it More Than the Others

abstract: Wildest day on Wall Street in four years
snippet: Wildest day on Wall Street in four years
lead_paragraph: The Dow today, at its high, was up more than 1 percent from yesterday. At its low, it was down more than 1 percent.
